title: EnglishPod 初级 英文播客 0092

segments.en: And today we are going back in time.
Alright, so we are going to the year 1950 and, well, we are going to look at some of the typical and common words and phrases that were used back in that year.
segments.cn: 好的，我们要回到1950年，看看那一年使用的一些典型和常见的单词和短语。

segments.en: Yes, all of these words and phrases you might still hear today, but they are really a little bit old-fashioned.
segments.cn: 是的，这些单词和短语你今天可能仍然会听到，但它们确实有点过时。

segments.en: Alright, so we have some words that we need to look at before we listen to our dialogue, so let's look at these words in vocabulary preview.
segments.cn: 好的，在我们听对话之前，我们需要看一些单词，所以让我们在词汇预览中看看这些单词。

segments.en: We have two words we're going to hear in the dialogue.
segments.cn: 我们在对话中会听到两个单词。

segments.en: Okay, now this is very old-fashioned and probably not used anymore.
segments.cn: 好吧，这个非常过时，可能不再使用了。

segments.en: But a sock hop is a school dance.
segments.cn: 但袜子舞是学校的舞会。

segments.en: Okay, so all the kids after school would get together and dance rock and roll in the gym or something.
segments.cn: 好的，所有孩子放学后会聚在一起，在体育馆跳摇滚乐。

segments.en: And, well, it's very popular and very common among American culture in those days.
segments.cn: 在那时候，这在美国文化中非常流行和常见。

segments.en: So you would still maybe see this in a movie or something like that.
segments.cn: 所以你可能在电影中仍然会看到这个。

segments.en: And our second word is still used today.
segments.cn: 而我们的第二个单词今天仍在使用。

segments.en: So a Sadie Hawkins dance is a dance when the girls ask the guys to be their date.
segments.cn: Sadie Hawkins舞是女孩邀请男孩做她们的约会。

segments.en: Okay, so it's a party and the guys don't invite the girls.
segments.cn: 好的，所以这是一个派对，男孩不邀请女孩。

segments.en: No, the girls invite the guys.
Okay, so it's a little bit of a reverse of roles there.
segments.cn: 好的，所以这有点角色反转。

segments.en: So in this case, the girls have to come up to the guys and say, hey, do you want to go to the dance with me?
segments.cn: 所以在这种情况下，女孩必须走到男孩面前说，嘿，你想和我一起去舞会吗？

segments.en: So this still happens today in North America, so you will probably hear it sometime.
segments.cn: 这在北美今天仍然发生，所以你可能会听到。

segments.en: And I guess now we could listen to our dialogue for the first time and it takes place at a high school.
segments.cn: 我想现在我们可以第一次听我们的对话，它发生在一所高中。

segments.en: Hey, Tracy, how are you doing?
Hey, listen, you want to go to the sock hop with me this Friday?
segments.cn: 嘿，听着，你想这个星期五和我一起去袜子舞吗？

segments.en: First of all, it's the Sadie Hawkins dance.
The girls got to ask the guys also.
So when are you going to ask me?
segments.cn: 那你什么时候要邀请我？

segments.en: I've had my eye on you for a while.
segments.cn: 我已经关注你一段时间了。

segments.en: Hey, buddy, ease off my girl, man.
Or do you want a knuckle sandwich?
segments.cn: 还是你想要一份拳头三明治？

segments.en: All right, so a little bit of a discussion over a girl.
segments.cn: 好吧，关于女孩的小争论。

segments.en: So we're going to be looking at some of these words that were maybe a little bit difficult in the dialogue in language takeaway.
segments.cn: 所以我们将看看对话中可能有点困难的一些单词，在语言收获中。

segments.en: Well, we've got five phrases and words from the dialogue.
segments.cn: 好吧，我们从对话中得到了五个短语和单词。

segments.en: Now, the first thing we heard was Sandy said, hey, yeah, hey, yeah, hey, yeah.
segments.cn: 首先我们听到的是Sandy说，嘿，是的，嘿，是的，嘿，是的。

segments.en: Now, an interjection, a way of saying hi, but very old fashioned.
segments.cn: 现在，一个感叹词，一种打招呼的方式，但非常过时。

segments.en: Basically, hi, you are Hey, you.
I guess you would still use it today, though, right?
segments.cn: 我想你今天仍然会使用它，对吧？

segments.en: Yeah, it's still a normal way to to greet someone.
segments.cn: 是的，这仍然是问候某人的正常方式。

segments.en: And what about our second word?
segments.cn: 那我们的第二个单词呢？

segments.en: Well, Sandy asked Tracy, how are you?
When you are swell, you are great.
And again, swell is an old fashioned way of saying I'm good or I'm great.
segments.cn: 而且，再次，"很好"是说我很好或我很棒的过时方式。

segments.en: But you would still hear it.
And it also is used to describe things.
Now for our next word, they got into a fight and Tracy said, cool it, guys.
segments.cn: 现在对于我们的下一个单词，他们打了一架，Tracy说，冷静点，伙计们。

segments.en: So why don't we listen to some examples of cool it before we explain it.
segments.cn: 所以在我们解释之前，为什么我们不听一些冷静点的例子。

segments.en: This is one my dad used to say to me and my sisters all the time.
segments.cn: 这是我爸爸经常对我和我姐妹说的。

segments.en: So it is still very commonly used, I would say.
segments.cn: 所以我可以说这仍然是非常常用的。

segments.en: Now for our last two words.
segments.cn: 现在是我们最后两个词。

segments.en: These are a little bit more old fashioned.
They talk about a knuckle sandwich.
segments.cn: 他们谈论的是“拳头三明治”。

segments.en: He says, do you want a knuckle sandwich?
segments.cn: 他说，你想要一个拳头三明治吗？

segments.en: What are we talking about here?
Well, on your hand, you have above your fingers, you have your knuckles.
segments.cn: 嗯，在你的手上，手指上方有你的指关节。

segments.en: So those are the bumpy parts on my hand.
segments.cn: 所以那些是我手上的凸起部分。

segments.en: The bones on the top part of your hand.
So he's basically saying, do you want me to punch you?
segments.cn: 所以他基本上是在说，你想让我打你吗？

segments.en: Do you want me to hit you with my hand, with my fist?
segments.cn: 你想让我用手，拳头打你吗？

segments.en: So it's a very informal way of saying a punch, knuckle sandwich.
segments.cn: 所以这是一个非常非正式的说法，指的是打击，拳头三明治。

segments.en: I'll give you a knuckle sandwich.
segments.cn: 我会给你一个拳头三明治。

segments.en: And for our last word, he called, Tommy called Sandy a pipsqueak.
segments.cn: 对于我们的最后一个词，他称汤米为“小家伙”。

segments.en: Now this is kind of an insult, but again, very old fashioned.
segments.cn: 现在这有点侮辱，但又是非常过时的。

segments.en: A pipsqueak is a very small person, right?
segments.cn: 小家伙是一个非常小的人，对吧？

segments.en: A small person who is not strong.
So a small and weak person.
segments.cn: 所以是一个小而弱的人。

segments.en: I guess nowadays you can still call somebody pipsqueak, but maybe in a lighter sense.
segments.cn: 我想现在你仍然可以称某人为小家伙，但可能是以更轻松的方式。

segments.en: It would be a little bit funny to call someone a pipsqueak.
segments.cn: 称某人为小家伙会有点搞笑。

segments.en: Why don't we listen to our dialogue again?
We're going to slow it down a little bit so you can get all these words that we just looked at.
segments.cn: 我们会慢一点，这样你可以理解我们刚刚看到的所有词。

segments.en: And then we'll come back and look at some phrases.
segments.cn: 然后我们会回来看看一些短语。

segments.en: Hey buddy, ease off my girl, man.
Or do you want a knuckle sandwich?
segments.cn: 否则你想要一个拳头三明治吗？

segments.en: So that was a little bit easier to understand, but some great 50s style phrases and words.
segments.cn: 所以这有点容易理解，但一些很棒的50年代风格的短语和词。

segments.en: So why don't we look at some of these phrases now in Fluency Builder.
segments.cn: 所以我们现在来看看这些短语吧，在流利构建器中。

segments.en: Alright, on Fluency Builder today we're going to look at three phrases.
segments.cn: 好吧，今天在流利构建器中我们将看三个短语。

segments.en: Why don't we start with the first one.
segments.cn: 我们为什么不从第一个开始。

segments.en: Sandy said that the party will be a blast.
So if something is a blast, it's very fun.
segments.cn: 所以如果某事很有趣，那就是非常有趣。

segments.en: So the party was a blast.
I had a great time last night.
And you'll still hear this phrase used today.
segments.cn: 你今天仍然会听到这个短语。

segments.en: So Sandy said he had his eye on Tracy.
segments.cn: 所以桑迪说他对特雷西很感兴趣。

segments.en: He said, I've had my eye on you.
To have your eye on someone.
So if I have my eye on the new iPhone that came out.
segments.cn: 所以如果我关注新发布的iPhone。

segments.en: You are watching it carefully because you want it.
segments.cn: 你在仔细观察，因为你想要它。

segments.en: Okay, so I'm keeping my attention on it because I want it.
segments.cn: 好的，所以我在关注它，因为我想要它。

segments.en: I have my eye on that sweater because it's on sale.
segments.cn: 我关注那件毛衣，因为它在打折。

segments.en: So you really want that sweater.
segments.cn: 所以你真的想要那件毛衣。

segments.en: So to have your eye on something or on someone.

segments.cn: 对于我们的最后一个短语。

segments.en: Tommy told Sandy, Hey buddy, ease off my girl.
segments.cn: 汤米告诉桑迪，嘿，伙计，别碰我的女孩。

segments.en: So why don't we listen to some examples of how we could use ease off because it might be a little bit tricky and then we'll come back and talk about it.
segments.cn: 所以我们为什么不听一些关于如何使用放松的例子，因为这可能有点棘手，然后我们再回来讨论。

segments.en: You need to ease off the junk food.
Matt is putting so much pressure on me these days.
segments.cn: 马特最近给我施加了很多压力。

segments.en: I wish he would ease off.

segments.cn: 你对苏西施加的压力太大了。

segments.en: You need to ease off a bit.
Okay, so it looks like you say this phrase ease off.
segments.cn: 好吧，所以看起来你在说“放松一下”这个短语。

segments.en: When somebody is putting pressure on you or doing something to you that they shouldn't.
segments.cn: 当有人对你施加压力或做一些他们不该做的事情时。

segments.en: Maybe they're being too intense or maybe annoying you.
segments.cn: 也许他们太过强烈，或者让你感到烦恼。

segments.en: So you tell them, hey, ease off.
segments.cn: 所以你告诉他们，嘿，放松一下。
放松一下对油腻食物的摄入。
所以有一些很好的短语。

segments.en: I think it's a good idea for us to listen to our dialogue one more time and then we'll come back and talk a little bit more about the 1950s.
segments.cn: 我认为我们再听一遍对话是个好主意，然后我们再回来多聊聊1950年代。
所以1950年代，一个美好的时代。

segments.en: And this is the first of a small series that we're going to have of different words and phrases that were used back in the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s, etc.
segments.cn: 这是我们将要进行的小系列的第一部分，内容是1950年代、1960年代、1970年代等时期使用的不同单词和短语。

segments.en: So a little bit more time travel is coming up here in EnglishPod.
segments.cn: 所以这里还有更多的时间旅行即将到来，欢迎来到EnglishPod。

segments.en: Because a lot of these phrases are still used and you might even see them in movies or if you're talking to somebody that was maybe born in these eras, they might even still use them today.
segments.cn: 因为很多这些短语仍然在使用，你甚至可能在电影中看到它们，或者如果你和一些可能出生于这些时代的人交谈，他们今天可能仍然会使用这些短语。

segments.en: So do you guys know any English phrases or slangs from the 1950s?
segments.cn: 所以你们知道1950年代的任何英语短语或俚语吗？

segments.en: Why don't you visit our website at EnglishPod.com to tell us about it.
segments.cn: 为什么不访问我们的网站EnglishPod.com告诉我们呢。

segments.en: And also if you have questions or comments, please leave them on the comment section as well.
segments.cn: 如果你有问题或评论，请在评论区留言。

segments.en: Well, thanks for listening and until next time.
segments.cn: 好吧，感谢你的收听，下次再见。
